Award.AwardTitle: PIRE: Mapping Evolutionary Process in the Face of Climate Change: An Integrated Approach to Education and Conservation Prioritization in Central Africa
Award.AbstractNarration:
The overarching research goal of this project is to develop an integrated framework for conserving Central African biodiversity under climate change that is both evolutionarily-informed and grounded in the socioeconomic constraints of the region. Central African rainforests represent one of the most important centers of biological diversity in the world. While efforts have been made to prioritize regions for protection, habitat loss continues at an alarming rate severely limiting the ability of species to respond to climate change. This project unites researchers and students from the U.S., Cameroon, Gabon, United Kingdom, Germany, France and the Netherlands around an innovative research program that seeks to identify meaningful conservation measures to mitigate the effects of habitat loss and climate change. The international team will use multi-disciplinary approaches to: 1) map environmentally-associated genomic and phenotypic variation in a broad range of species and assess how this overlaps with patterns of species richness and protected areas; 2) evaluate how evolutionary adaptation, phenotypic plasticity and landscape connectivity might mediate future threats; and 3) develop an integrated prioritization scheme that ranks candidate areas for protection on their evolutionary potential, connectivity, estimated socioeconomic costs, degree of threat and cultural value.

This project involves a broad range of partnerships between U.S., European and African universities, non-governmental organization and governmental agencies. Planned educational activities will promote scientific collaboration and exchange between partners through: 1) undergraduate and graduate educational programs that will partner U.S. and African students and provide cutting-edge training in the biological, environmental and social sciences; 2) annual professional development workshops for early career U.S. and African scientists and advanced graduate students; 3) region-wide research symposia and scientific exchange; 4) bilingual distance-learning programs; and 5) outreach to decision makers through policy workshops. This integrative program aligns well with NSF's Science, Engineering, and Education for Sustainability (SEES) program objectives in developing a workforce of globally engaged young investigators whose coordinated efforts will focus on sustainability science and education. These joint international research and educational efforts will enhance existing collaborations and establish new partnerships that will build a foundation for lasting conservation and sustainability in Central Africa. The project is funded by NSF's Office of International Science and Engineering (OISE).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Congo Basin and Gulf of Guinea rainforests are one of the most important centers of biological diversity, harboring one out of every five species on Earth. While efforts have been made to prioritize regions for protection, habitat conversion and deforestation continue at an alarming rate. Forest loss and land use changes are not only affecting populations of species currently inhabiting these regions, but also limiting the ability of future populations to respond to climate change. Previous conservation strategies have used measures such as levels of species richness and species rarity for planning but have rarely incorporated the evolutionary processes that produce and maintain biological diversity.

Our project's goal was to develop an integrated framework for conserving Central African biodiversity under climate change, which was both evolutionary-informed and grounded in the socioeconomic constraints of the region. Focusing on Cameroon and Gabon, the four specific objectives were to: 

1) Map environmentally-associated genomic and phenotypic variation in a broad range of species to identify areas of high turnover where species capacity to adapt was greatest and assess how these areas of elevated turnover overlap with hotspots of species richness and protected areas;

2) Evaluate how evolutionary adaptation, phenotypic plasticity, and landscape connectivity might mediate future threats;

3) Develop an integrated prioritization scheme that ranks candidate areas for protection on their evolutionary potential, connectivity, estimated socioeconomic costs, and degree of threat;

4) Promote education, training, and capacity building in sets relevant to this project.

Integrating across seven taxa, including birds, mammals, insects, amphibians and plants, results showed:

(1) The main areas in Cameroon and Gabon where the highest intraspecific genomic turnover is found were across the forest-savanna ecotone and elevational gradients along the Cameroon montane line.

(2) The highest species richness was found in South Central Cameroon and highest levels of endemism in the Cameroon mountains.

(3) The highest genomic vulnerability, a measure of how much populations need to evolve to maintain genotype-environment relationships under future climate warming; based on a 2080 scenario using IPCC RCP 4.5.

In some cases, we found that for species to persist, some areas of high genomic vulnerability populations will need to evolve at a rate 300 times faster than they have done since the last glacial maximum 18,000 years ago. 

To ensure that our research results were used to inform policy and decision making, we met with over 150 representatives from national governments and non-governmental organizations in the very first year of the project to communicate the goals of project. This was followed by periodic updates as the project progressed. At the end of the project, two capstone policy workshops were held in Cameroon and Gabon where invited decision-makers reviewed the scientific and socio-economic data generated by the project, and used the results to prioritize conservation areas based on projected climate change. Through this collaborative process, decision makers were engaged throughout the project. This ensured that results of the project would be available and more likely used in decision making.

Educational and scientific exchange and capacity building was an important component of the project, uniting senior investigators, junior researchers, and students from across the U.S., Africa (Cameroon, Gabon, Equatorial Guinea), Europe (Germany, U.K.), and Asia (China, Hong Kong) into a common research and education plan. Over 400 students from four countries participated in trainings and workshops we offered, including intensive multi-week field biology courses that generated novel scientific findings. We partnered with COACh, a grassroots organization focused on increasing the success of women in science, to offer trainings specifically for women in STEM, and our courses included a diverse range of students, including African Americans and Africans. We organized annual field courses for undergrads and Professional Development Workshops for graduate students on a rotating basis in Cameroon and Gabon.

Over 130 faculty researchers, post-doctoral researchers, and graduate students participated in research and trainings, and 60 undergraduate students received hands on experience in laboratory work and tropical ecology research. The socio-economics research component of the project organized focus groups in Cameroon and Gabon. The data from these groups demonstrated that climate change has been associated with reduced crop productivity and school attendance.

To date, the project has produced scores of peer-reviewed publications, with additional ones under preparation. The project and its results have been covered in media outlets 40 times, and included a TED talk that attracted nearly one million views.

The project will have lasting impacts on research and education in the Congo Basin through the Congo Basin Institute (CBI). The project helped create CBI which has allowed work to continue beyond the life of the project. CBI offers classroom, research, and lodging space in Cameroon, including two biological field stations that were re-opened during this project. CBI currently operates in six sub Saharan countries and has attracted 15 institutional partners.
